messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level B1

Text saved: There are more questions about how genetics influence brain and language development, and scientists want to know if there are special **genes**, which are the instructions inside our bodies, that changed and gave us the ability to speak. Researchers have found a gene that changed between 100,000 and 200,000 years ago, and this change seems to be connected with speaking and how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not have this change. However, it is too early to say how much influence genes have on language, but one day the answers might be found in our DNA.
Feedback received: Grade 4/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: CEFR Compliance. The text was classified as 'B2' instead of the target 'B1'. The primary reason for this is the first sentence: 'There are more questions about how genetics influence brain and language development, and scientists want to know if there are special genes, which are the instructions inside our bodies, that changed and gave us the ability to speak.' This sentence is too long and structurally complex for a B1 level, containing multiple embedded clauses. Suggestion: Break this sentence into two or three shorter sentences to improve readability and meet the B1 standard. For example: 'Scientists have more questions about how genetics influence the brain and language. They want to know if special genes changed and gave us the ability to speak. Genes are the instructions inside our bodies.' The rest of the text handles vocabulary well, but this structural issue is a critical failure.

Scientists want to know if a change in these instructions gave us the ability to speak. Researchers have found a change in these instructions that happened between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago. This change seems to be connected with speaking. It is also connected with how our brains control our mouths and face. Monkeys have a similar instruction, but it did not have this same change. It is too early to say how much influence these instructions have on language, but the answers might one day be found in our DNA.
